Nearshore extent. The maximum observed DHW (Degree Heating Week) per pixel was calculated over the time frame of the data (2013-2016). Pixels exceeding 12 DHW were set to the maximum value since it is likely that major coral mortality has occurred those areas.

Footprint of terrestrial aquaculture facilities.
Aquarium fishing take is reported to DAR separately from food fish, under a different licensing scheme and reporting system.
Modeled reef fish catch from commercial and recreational fishery taking into account shoreline accessibility.
Benthic structures were defined as manmade features in the offshore environment that disrupt benthic habitat and include moored buoys, channel markers, offshore cables and pipelines.

column3: habitat destruction caused by coastal engineering
column6: Coastal engineering consisted of shoreline armoring structures (e.g., seawalls, revetments, groins, break waters), artificial land (i.e., land fill), and piers.
Dredging was defined as activity involving physically removing substrate with machinery typically to allow for safe passage of vessels
Represents presence-only of invasive algae species in nearshore waters and mangroves along the shoreline.
Onsite waste disposal systems (ODSD) as proxy of nitrogen flux to the nearshore water.

column3: land-based sediment export to nearshore water
column6: Falinski (2016) customized, parameterized, calibrated, and ran the Integrated Valuation of Ecosystem Services and Tradeoffs (InVEST) model for sediment delivery for each of the eight Main Hawaiian Islands. This model predicts the average annual amount of sediment (tons/yr) exported from each map pixel as a function of land use/land cover, soil characteristics, rainfall, slope, geology, and hydrology.

column3: land-based source of pollution from agriculture and golf courses
column6: Proxy for agricultural and landscaping runoff (nutrients from fertilizers; chemicals like pesticides and herbicides), calculated as the area of agricultural land and golf courses by watershed

column3: land-based source of pollution from urban runoff
column6: Proxy for nutrient and chemical pollution
State of Hawaii Division of Aquatic Resources aerial imagery of marine debris from 2015.
To represent the risk of ship groundings and wrecks the footprint of this ship traffic layer was clipped to 9 m depth.
Ship traffic layer was used as a proxy for ship-based pollution.

column3: direct impacts from humans (trampling, recreation, etc)
column6: InVEST recreation model was run statewide at 1 km resolution for the years 2005 - 2014. This model uses publicly visible geotagged photos posted to the photo-sharing website Flickr to calculate the annual average number of photo users per day per grid cell
